title: Espresso Troubleshooting: Fix Sour, Bitter, and Weak Shots
excerpt: Is your espresso sour, bitter, or watery? This complete troubleshooting guide shows you exactly how to fix common espresso problems and dial in perfect shots.
content:
The Three Most Common Problems

Almost all espresso issues fall into three categories: sour (under-extracted), bitter (over-extracted), or weak/watery. Let's fix each one.

Problem 1: Sour Espresso

What It Means

Sour, tart, or acidic shots indicate under-extraction. Not enough flavor compounds have been dissolved from the coffee grounds.

Quick Fixes

  1. Grind finer: This is usually the culprit. Go 1-2 steps finer on your grinder.
  2. Increase dose: Add 0.5-1g more coffee to your basket.
  3. Raise temperature: If your machine has temperature control, increase by 1-2°C.
  4. Extend brew time: Aim for 25-30 seconds instead of 20-25.

Check These Too

  • Bean freshness: Beans less than 5 days post-roast can be difficult to extract. Wait a few more days.
  • Roast level: Very light roasts are harder to extract and may always taste slightly sour. This might be intentional.
  • Water temperature: Make sure your machine is fully warmed up.

Problem 2: Bitter Espresso

What It Means

Harsh, bitter, or astringent shots indicate over-extraction. Too many bitter compounds have been extracted from the coffee.

Quick Fixes

  1. Grind coarser: Go 1-2 steps coarser on your grinder.
  2. Decrease dose: Reduce by 0.5-1g.
  3. Lower temperature: Decrease by 1-2°C if possible.
  4. Shorten brew time: Aim for 20-25 seconds instead of 25-30.

Check These Too

  • Stale beans: Beans older than 4-6 weeks can taste flat and bitter.
  • Dark roast: Very dark roasts are easier to over-extract. Use cooler temps.
  • Dirty equipment: Old coffee oils can add rancid bitterness. Clean your machine!
  • Channeling: Uneven extraction can cause both sour and bitter notes.

Problem 3: Weak/Watery Espresso

What It Means

Thin body, lack of flavor intensity, watery texture. Usually means water is flowing too fast.

Quick Fixes

  1. Grind much finer: This is almost always the issue. Go 3-5 steps finer.
  2. Increase dose: More coffee creates more resistance.
  3. Check your basket: Pressurized baskets can cause weak shots. Upgrade to precision basket.
  4. Pre-infusion: If your machine has it, enable pre-infusion for better saturation.

Check These Too

  • Brew time under 20 seconds: Way too fast. Grind finer immediately.
  • Tamping pressure: Make sure you're tamping with consistent 30lb pressure.
  • Distribution: Uneven coffee distribution can cause channels (water shortcuts).

Problem 4: Channeling

What It Means

Water finds the path of least resistance, creating channels through the puck. Results in uneven extraction (sour AND bitter at the same time).

How to Spot It

  • Spurts or jets in your bottomless portafilter
  • Very fast flow in certain spots
  • Blonde spots appearing early in the shot
  • Inconsistent shots (good one time, bad the next)

Solutions

  1. WDT (Weiss Distribution Technique): Use a thin needle to break up clumps before tamping.
  2. Consistent tamping: Tamp level with even pressure every time.
  3. Fresh beans: Super fresh (<3 days) or very stale beans clump more.
  4. Better basket: IMS or VST precision baskets help reduce channeling.
  5. Proper dosing: Don't overfill or underfill your basket.

Problem 5: Inconsistent Shots

What It Means

Some shots are great, others are terrible, with no obvious changes.

Solutions

  1. Weigh everything: Use a scale for dose in and yield out. Consistency requires precision.
  2. Temperature surfing: If no PID, follow the same routine every time.
  3. Workflow consistency: Time from grinding to extraction affects the shot. Keep it consistent.
  4. Check grinder retention: Old grounds mixing with fresh can cause issues. Purge grinder.

The Systematic Approach

When troubleshooting, follow this priority order:

  1. Grind size: Adjust first (biggest impact)
  2. Dose: Fine-tune second
  3. Temperature: Adjust third (if possible)
  4. Everything else: Distribution, tamping, etc.
Change ONE variable at a time! Otherwise you won't know what fixed (or broke) your shot.
